segments.text: their strong points and their assets.
So I began to write things for them.
And the first March I wrote for them, Vern was still there, that old men of Kyle, which they've been still been playing that now for 27 years.
And they, they, everywhere they go, they play it.
And so then I could see that since it was predominantly brass, that the woodwinds were just, just filling the hole really.

so we began to really expound on that a lot and really the sound became almost unique because uh and the first i wanted them to go over to the sidelines and halt and play right in front of the people so they could see how good they were well this had never been done they did not want to do it but i was established
pretty good by then, and the drum major I had, I said, this is the guy that I think we can do it with.
So I wrote a medley of tunes called the Blue Gray Medley, which they played up until just a few years ago.
And it had Yellow Rose of Texas, and it had the Bonnie Blue Flag.
I wrote that for Travis Bryan, because that's his favorite song in this world.
and then it had Dixie, which they let us play, and then it had the Battle Hymn of the Republic.
And it was just for us and nobody else.
So anyway, I talked to him, and he said, well, sir, I'll go.
I said, I want you to go talk to the drum major now and see what they think about it, and then I want you to come back and let's all get together and see what you think.
Well, so they came in there.
Well, sir, we never have done that before.
I said, well, do you see anything wrong with it, why we shouldn't do it?
And they said, well, no, sir, I don't see any reason why we shouldn't do it.
I said, well, do you like the way the band sounds now?
Do you think we've come a long way with their sound?
And they said, well, yes, sir, we have.
And I said, well, I'll tell you what I'll do.
I want you to try this one time.
And if they don't throw programs in the air and throw hats around and you don't get a roaring standing ovation,
Well, then I'll never ask you to do it again.
And old Brad Harrison, he said, well, that's fair enough.
So we marched him.
And when he came, well, then we flanked over right over the sideline, man.
And it was about the time we got to that battle at the end of the public.
I get goose pimples every time I think about it.
And boy, they blew the end.
They'd never heard the Aggie band like that before, ever.
And they blew the ends out of those horns.
And it was really a major accomplishment for us.
And they threw programs and hats.
We got letters from all over everywhere.
So then they came in and they apologized.
And I've got a letter in my scrapbook in there from this same drum major.
And they've been doing it ever since.

But you've got to get right under the mouth of the gun sometime and really just really let them know that we play as well as the, because see the Texas band, the Texas Tech band, they all come over and play all the time.
So we're marching down the field constantly.
And all our sound is going that way.
And then coming back it's going that way.
And nobody really knows, if you don't do something like that, just how good that band really is.
So, boy, they said, well, we can go over to the side and we can do this.
And it really made a difference.
I think it made a... That's one of the first things we really did that started us on the way to expand our...
our musical talents.
So anyway, then the band seemed to get so popular that everybody wanted them somewhere.
This happened in about the, we'd have our standard things we'd go to, you know.
and we'd go to 12 football games and we'd go to 12 basketball games we'd go to the six reviews and we'd go to the uh battle flowers parade and maybe one other and then that that was it for the year

And then all of a sudden they started, all these people wanted them to come, the Fat Stock Show, and they wanted them to come to the Mardi Gras, and they wanted them to come to the sailing, what did they call that, the sailing of the fleet down at Corpus.
So then I changed the military setup mainly to get rid of them.

lot of the guys got to be seniors and they didn't have any rank at all and they didn't so we we divided the band and made a brigade out of the band we had over 300 every year and we divided it into into two two units which gave
these other seniors an opportunity to be officers, twice as many.
And that seemed to help more than anything else we did.
And this really, we could call it the maroon band and the white band or whatever you want to call it, but it had two battalions instead of one.
of these various trips, year after year after year, which one was your favorite, most enjoyable?
Well, you know, we had so many.
We started going when Jackie Sherrill came, but he wanted us to go everywhere he went.
And Jackie Sherrill was here, I think, six or eight years.
We missed two football games.
Two.
And one of them was in southern Mississippi and the other was Alabama.
It was just not feasible for us to go to either one of them at the time and everything.
And I think they're doing about the same now.
And Jackie was very, very helpful.
And it would be very difficult for me to say which one was the best.
I think the trip we made to the Meadowland for the Kickoff Classic was one of the notable ones when Jackie was here.
And then of course the inaugural parade for President Bush, that was a wonderful trip.
We flew, we'd go to Arkansas every year.
Those were not so memorable, and LSU, but the last year I was here we went out of state five times.
Now the funding for those trips came from what source?
I wanted them to set up a budget for it, but they didn't do it.
It was just, you know, if the Board of Regents decided we wanted to go somewhere, they'd say, okay, yeah, they'll be there.
Well, where are we going to get the money?
Oh, well, let's see, so-and-so will give $25, you'll give $50, you'll give $50.
And then when it comes time to giving the money, they wouldn't give it.
And it always prolonged everything, but they would raise the money.
Now Jackie went to see the former students, Randy Mattson.
And Randy and Jackie made a deal that they were going to give $25,000 every year so
The $25,000 would go to the Texas trip one year, the Arkansas trip the next year.
And then when we'd fly, man, that cost a fortune.
We spent $300,000 that last year.
I was there just on trips.
And maybe more.
I'd go in there and ask for a couple of bass horns and piccolos and say you know we don't have any money.
You know how that goes.
But anyway, and they've been going and it's much more now than it was then.
So they've been really traveling now.
I would think that the Meadowlands, or that we played the Kickoff Classic, or the Inaugural Parade, General Darling went with us up there, and we just had a lot of fun.
Was there any of the kind of regular trips you made that were more difficult to deal with than the others?
Yeah, when I first came here,
Everywhere we went, we had to go on bus.
We played in the Hall of Fame Bowl in Virginia, I believe.
We had to get on a bus, ride all night long,
and then play the game, get on the bus, and come back.
And we used to do the same thing at Texas Tech.
So I had about all, I'd go in, and I'd say, man, I'll tell you what, now this is no, and everybody else, man, they'd get buses and overnight, but we couldn't stay overnight.

but so I go in and talk to General Simpson about it and he agreed and then John agreed so then on the big trips like Tech, Arkansas, LSU, any of those then they started letting us spend the night and if we had to go out of state like we went to the Sun Bowl when Emery Ballard was there and we got to fly out there
And then we got, next thing we know, we got a little deal that the athletic department agreed that anytime we have to go out of state, we fly.
And the athletic department was just absolutely marvelous to me and to the band.
So they helped fund that?
They helped.
You know, they started asking for donations at the first Cotton Bowl we went to, and they got a whole bunch the first year.
I don't know what they're getting now, and they got a whole bunch the second year.
And they paid for an awful lot of stuff.
During your years, are there any donors that deserve special appreciation?
Well, we didn't have many donors, really.
We didn't have any scholarships.
And they offered us a couple.
The son, Ross, came to me and said they wanted to give a couple scholarships.
And I said, well, I'll talk it over with the officers in the band.
And you know, this sounds kind of silly, but this is true.
And we had the COs in there, and we had the drum major.
And we talked about it and talked about it.
And I said, then we had to decide who's going to get it and how they're going to get it.
So they talked it over and came back in and said, we don't want any scholarships.
He said, who's going to get it?
Who's better than I am?
Who's better than he is?
I mean that's just the way they were.
And I think there's a big difference in the, I don't say the attitude, but the way things were run then and now.
That was definitely an old army back in those days, and it's not that way now.
In your years, organizationally, you reported directly to John Colas?
General Simpson.
I did the first year to John Colas, and then General Simpson came in, and so he was my boss up until...
He retired, then Howard Perry was my boss.
And then the last three or four years there, General Darling was my boss.
And they moved us into the Corps entirely.
And so General Darling was my boss.
And I can truthfully say that he's one of the nicest, finest gentlemen I believe I've ever known.
And I really do have a lot of admiration for him.
And we, you know, so see, I wouldn't actually...
connected with or responsible to the military people over there they wish I was but I wasn't and so that's the setup we had and so then you know they would have to I wanted them to set up a budget
for our travels and they never would.

And so I said well it just made it real hard for us to function on our budget because what they did was go ahead and spend our money and then we couldn't go over there and even get money for our requisitions or anything.
But anyway it worked I guess.
You came as the, your title was assistant or associate director?
Associate director.
I was the first one they had.
And you did that for one year.
And then I became the director in 73.
I was here in 72 as associate director.
Describe in those years the process of how a youngster became a member of the Aggie band.
How did they?
Okay, the first thing, we sent out information to almost every high school in the state about the band.
And then mostly, all of the guys in the band would go to their hometown
They would go see the principal.
They would set up a night of recruiting in their own high school and take movies and show and have information, answer all the questions about the band.
Then they would write to me.
And I would, we'd go back and forth.
And then they would have these conferences.
The individual prospect.
Yes, yes.
Then they would have these conferences.
And we would sign these people up.
And although there was no formal audition, they had to see, to see me or my, one of my assistants and get, go through the conference and fill out this sheet.
And then, you know, if you had a first chair, all state player from spring and well, he's not going to sit down and play the third part, you know how good he is.
And so we, you know, the core was getting smaller.
And then we had

our our recruiting was not near as good in the last four five six years although we we stayed right around 300 uh the most we ever had was 358 and now there's core developments you know i think they give 250 scholarships a year and they're up to 400. well see we didn't have any of that yeah and it was tough during those years which instruments
Generally were you, did you have a large number of prospects and for which instruments a few?
You usually had all of the bass horns you wanted.
We would have 34, from 33 to 36, 38 bass horns every year.
One year we had 76 trombones.
One year we had 94 trumpets.
But you take your general instrumentation in those days, and this was, it's just amazing how every year it was about like this.
You start with your flutes, you'd have two, maybe, piccolos, maybe 10, 12 clarinets.
And then you go to your saxophones, you'd have 40 alto saxophones, you'd have 40 tenors, somewhere in the neighborhood of 40 tenors.
25 French horns, then trombones 60 to 70, baritone horns 20, 25, trumpets probably 65 to 85, and predominantly brass.
What about percussion?
Oh yeah, no problem with percussion.
We'd always, we marched, they used to have three bass drums,
And I always felt like the bass drums, you should just see them and know they're there.
It's not a bass drum solo.
So they'd get pretty hot sometime about that, but I insisted.
They thought they were the reason that the band was staying together, so they're going to wear out a bass drum beater every week.
That's not right.
So we'd have two rows of percussion, which was 24.
We'd have two set of cymbals and two bass drums.
So when they divided up, there'd be one on each.
And usually that's the way it worked out.
But you know generally speaking that was, it was all brass.
So I gave, I let the clarinet parts play, clarinets would play trumpet parts, because unless you were starting strides you'd have your piccolos.
Some of you would get a real good piccolo player but you know and then we took in the girls and well that was a five year deal.
Let's talk about that in a minute.
Were there any bands that were unusually productive, any high school bands, of Aggie band members?
Yeah, we got a lot of them from Houston.
Well, most of the Houston schools would get a lot of them from Spring and Memorial, and they were the best ones usually as far as the instruments are concerned.
You get a lot from over in East Texas, you get a lot of Longview, Piler, Pine Tree, Lufkin.
and get quite a few from Dallas.
Then out west Texas, sometimes we get one from El Paso and Abilene and that.
But they, and San Antonio, we get a lot from San Antonio down there.
MacArthur was the main one.
They seem like we got a lot of them from MacArthur.
But the large schools usually we got a bunch of them.
Do you have any anecdotes you could share about someone trying to twist your arm to be sure that a certain youngster got in a band?
Oh, well, of course, most of those folks think that if they had a child that was really a nice boy and he was really a good boy,
that if I wanted him in the band I could get him in the band.
That's not so.
They had to have, they were interested in academic accomplishments or you don't get in.
Of course that's what I'd try to tell them and they still didn't believe it.
So most of the guys you know that came in there had IQs, SAT scores were at 1150.
But you'd get some time, you'd have four or five.
I remember one time in Conroe, four or five guys came in there and sat down, all of them nice looking boys.
And I said, well, what do you play?
I play trumpet, sir.
I was all regional.
I play trombone all state.
And then, so what do you play?
Sir, I'm percussion.
I'm an all state percussion player.
So I said, last one, what do you play?
Sir, I don't play anything.
And they said, sir, this is kind of a deal.
Said, if we get these four in, we'd like to get him in.
And I said, well, we don't have anybody.
And they had about 30 in the band when I came, but didn't play anything.
So I said, we don't do that now.
You play something if you're going to be in the band.
And so they looked and said, well, sir, we kind of plan on all being together.
I said, well, what would you like to play?
And he would say, I don't know.
You want to play anything?
If you're going to be in the band, you've got to play a horn.
What's the easiest?
I said, well, saxophone, percussion.
I said, would you be willing to learn how to play?
And we'd have about four or five of these every year.
He said, yes, sir, I would.
I'd like to do that.
I said, OK, I will arrange it for you to have a private lesson a week until you can play.
And then you will be allowed to march.
And Jay, see he was trying to get his music degree and I'd stick him on Jay and he'd teach him.
And so therefore we didn't have anybody that did not play.

Now the degree of accomplishment was sometimes not as great as others, but I had one of the CO in the band came from over here at Lafayette, Louisiana and that rascal, he'd never played in his life and he picked the flute.
And he was first chair in the flute in the concert band when he left.
I mean, he was good.
He played the start of the piccolo, you know.
And that's the kind they were.
And that's what they learned.
Saxophone is real easy.
You just have to punch a star below.
And, you know, in six weeks' time, you can play a saxophone and play most of the parts.
It's an easy part to play, too.
So anyway, that's the way we managed it.
And a lot of the mothers would call and say, well, my son's off state, and he did this, and he did that, and he did that.
I said, what's his SAT score?
She said, well, it's 1150.
I said, you won't have any trouble.
How'd he finish in his class?
I believe he was six or seven.
You just come right on.
I don't think you'll have any trouble at all.
But then on the other hand, you get a good one, and they said, well, it's about 700.
I said, I don't think he can get in.
And that's true.
In your years, when did the fall season begin for the Aggie band?
It started during Corps Orientation Week.

and they would have just the freshmen and that's usually the about the last week in August except if we had to do something real special like an early football game well then then we could sometime they let us come in early but see they didn't want to come in early because they had to pay for their rooms in the dorm and nobody wanted to pay for it
So that's why we couldn't do a lot of this.
Like when we went to Meadowlands, they came a week early.
But we'd take just the freshmen that week.
We'd teach them all the basic steps, left face, right face, the rear march, and how to march 65.
We'd teach them two or three simple little drills, and all week long, two hours a day, I'd be right there, and the drum majors would be there, and that's what we did with them.
So they worked out only, they marched, practiced marching two hours a day.
That first orientation week.
Were they also practicing instrumentally in addition?
No, they were not.
We just didn't have time.
See they were also going to all the other choral classes and they were getting orientated on their English and their history and they were signing up and they were registering.
It was a wonderful thing because they were a week ahead.
Then we wouldn't let the sophomores come.
Boy, they were tough.
It was tough.
We wouldn't let them mess with them until the following week.
Only a select few were there to stay with them.
And they tried to make it as pleasant as possible.
And then it's just an absolutely amazing the following week when they got there, most of them could go right in there.
They looked like they marched in.
Most of them had been doing that stuff, you know.
I don't know how they did it, but they did.
We'd get them out there on that drill field, and we'd work them.
They'd have plenty of ice water out there.
They'd get hot, go get under the shade, blah, blah, blah.
And that was really a good thing, I can tell you.
They're still doing it, too.
Now, the drill field in those days for the band was south of Duncan?
It's right there.
Yeah, right the way it is now.
Yeah, yeah.
And what time of day was that, two hours?
Five o'clock.
Oh, you mean for them?
Usually it would be, we'd get an hour probably in the morning and then an hour in the afternoon.
But we couldn't have but one hour.
And now I looked at the schedule.
I was up there the other day and Jay told me the schedule.
They're going to get them all week.
They're going to get to play and that's all they're going to do.
Well, that's wonderful, man.
We just didn't have that luxury in those days.
You know, everybody thought we got too much time and attention anyway, and we just didn't get it.
Now, when classes started, what was the routine then?
Okay, they go to their classes, and we have it.
We have one hour a day, 5 o'clock.
It was from 5 to 6.
And we had every one of those guys registered as a P class from five to six.
As the time went on and it got so crowded we couldn't get them all in but we got most of them in.
And then from four to five those that did not have classes would come in the band hall and we'd have a section rehearsal, get all the music straight.
go over all the points.
By then I'd have all the music worked out by the step as to how many steps in the drill and where to end it in the music.
You can do that just an absolute step if you just work at it.
And it was really quite a deal.
We didn't have but an hour and
And I said, man, we got to practice smarter, not harder.
We got to do every square minute of this has got to be learning something.
And, you know, it takes them.
So we'd go the first two days without music, just the percussion, and we'd walk through the drill.
We'd get that down pretty good.
And then on Wednesday, we'd put it with the music.
And that was just, I hated Wednesdays.
Because they couldn't, you know, they had to remember it.
But anyway, usually by Friday it was worked out pretty good and it was pretty solid.
And then we'd go Friday afternoon, we'd get to practice down at the field because that was, it was on astroturf then.
And we'd go down there early and have a little yell practice for the football team.
They finished at five.
And we went on at five.
And normally when you went on the road, you also practiced on their field on a farm?
Well, not much.
Oh, really?
No.
Occasionally we would if we needed it, but we didn't do that.
Most of them that came down here practiced on ours.

but we just go go do it and mainly because of the time factor and when we went to Fort Worth or to two places we'd go we'd have that corporate you know we didn't have time to practice on that now you you were the primary planner of the halftime routine I did I have one of them
All right.
And you would then share that first with what, would it be the Corps leaders?
Well, the first thing we did, we had a, I had a draftsman make me a simulated football field on a piece of paper.
I'll show you one if you want to see it.
And it had it all marked off in five yards and all the yard lines.
So I would draw the drills
on that paper.
Have you ever seen one of them?
And I'll show you the one we'll drill.
That's something.
And so then I would have the drum majors into my office usually
Either in the middle of about an hour before the drill or early in the morning if they couldn't come then, and I would give them their drill.
On Monday?
On Monday.
And if we played Texas on Thursday, we'd practice on Sunday.
They'd get it on Sunday.
And we would go over it step by step, and I would show them, okay, we'll do this and we'll do that.
Now here's a three-step counter march right here.
You know what that is.
We'd do a black here to get over there, and then you've got a cheetah step here.
And you had to do all that stuff or it wouldn't come out even.
So then they would go out there, and they would walk through it with the bugle ranks.
And the first, usually the first part of them company fronts, you couldn't do that.
They wouldn't have, but then the rest of it, they could march through it.
And then they had a pretty good idea of what was going to work by the time they got there.
And then they'd gather around, they'd explain it to the band.
Of course, the bugle rank then knew it.
They all got drills too.
So you'd do 12 for them, three for the drum majors, and three for the band directors.
Every week we'd do that.
And so that's the way it all worked out.
And we just didn't have time to clobber around, point everything out.

usually when they got out there and most of them were afraid not to do it right I think and they just did better than they know how sometimes now uh normally the routine is how long was how long the southwest conference rules stated that you could have eight minutes on and off the field now there's some schools that don't abide by that
Texas is on there usually every time 10 to 11 minutes.
But you're supposed to be on and off in 16 minutes, both fans, so the football teams then will have four minutes to get.
But usually it goes right up.

Now a lot of that sometimes you know you can't do it because there'll be people hanging around on the field, they can't get them off, so you get two or three minutes off your schedule, the teams might take a long time getting off, and it's really kind of difficult.
But eight was your target?
Eight minutes was your, and you go on longer than that, you've lost your audience anyway.
Right, then the opening routine in the north end zone for the inning band and the final block tee.
When you step off the field, it's supposed to be done in eight minutes.
Right, but I was going to ask, how much time was there between when they first stepped on the field at the end, after the bugle call, until they started?
playing in the block T, was that down to about six minutes?
Well I did it a lot quicker than that.
Because I told them, we don't want a minute of you saying recall, step off on .
That's right.
And we don't want to waste all this time there.
And also, we can't waste a minute on a bugle flourish, bugle rack flourish.
Unless we didn't have that much drill or something.
So you've got to do this quickly.
Because we are timed.
and said, I really do not care what the other people do.
We are going to be on and off, and if we can't get on, if we're not off in eight minutes, it's not going to be 15 seconds longer than that.
